channel.title: Ramah: Good News Feed
channel.description: Positive news stories from around the world, filtered by sentiment analysis

item.title: Japan election: Sanae Takaichi’s ruling conservatives on course for landslide win
item.description: Japan’s conservative governing party is on course to dramatically strengthen its grip on power after exit polls predicted a landslide victory in Sunday’s elections, in what will be seen as an early public endorsement of the new prime minister, Sanae Takaichi.

item.title: Drake Maye and the Patriots take on Sam Darnold and the Seahawks in Super Bowl 60
item.description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.

item.title: Breezy Johnson's downhill gold is America's first medal of 2026 Winter Olympics
item.description: U.S.

item.title: How to cook the perfect brigadeiros for Valentine’s Day – recipe | Felicity Cloake's How to cook the perfect …
item.description: If you’re not au fait with these soft, chocolatey treats, you clearly haven’t spent much time in Brazil, where, in the words of blogger Olivia Mesquita, they’re national treasures, “a must-have at special celebrations, from kids’ parties to weddings”.

item.title: Mystery plaintiff challenges Karl Lagerfeld’s will – but pampered cat can rest easy
item.description: The late German-born Chanel designer Karl Lagerfeld was famously precise, exacting and known to hold a grudge, but his final wishes concerning the beneficiaries of his vast fortune could now be overturned beyond the grave in a looming court battle.

item.title: ‘It has to be amazing’: Liberty links with Bridgerton as it capitalises on maximalist trend
item.description: On a damp Thursday in central London, shoppers have fled the rain to indulge in some Bridgerton-themed escapism at upmarket department store Liberty, which has dedicated its fourth floor to the raunchy period drama.

item.title: Peter Mandelson should hand back US ambassador payoff or give it to charity, says minister – UK politics live
item.description: The work and pensions secretary, Pat McFadden, has spoken to Trevor Phillips on his Sky News politics programme.

item.title: SA Liberals promise stamp duty relief as Labor shares plan for current WCH site
item.description: Less than six weeks from the South Australian election, the Liberal Party has announced an election promise on stamp duty relief.

item.title: For many U.S. Olympic athletes, Italy feels like home turf
item.description: In January, American athlete Jessie Diggins, the world's top-ranked female cross-country skier, sprinted up a steep slope in Italy's Val di Fiemme, poles pumping, for her third Tour de Ski victory.

item.title: Gold prospectors of bygone era create fond memories for photography duo
item.description: Photographers Roger Garwood and Trish Ainslie travelled to Western Australia's remote Goldfields in 1989 to capture prospectors who had been to war for a long-planned magazine feature.

item.title: Japanese people brave snow to vote in snap election
item.description: People across Japan are braving snow to vote in a snap election called by Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi, whose coalition is expected clinch a decisive win, according to polls.

item.title: Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi hopes for big win as polls open in national elections
item.description: TOKYO (AP) — Polls opened Sunday in parliamentary elections that Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi hopes will give her struggling party a big enough win to push through an ambitious conservative political agenda.

item.title: ‘Winds that sound like banshees’: residents told to take shelter as Pilbara braces for Tropical Cyclone Mitchell
item.description: Severe Tropical Cyclone Mitchell is expected to maintain its category 3 intensity as it barrels along the Pilbara coast before making landfall.

item.title: Savannah Guthrie says 'we will pay' for mother's safe return
item.description: US news anchor Savannah Guthrie and her family have released a new video pleading for the safe return of their mother.

item.title: Photographer turns cartwheels to snap the perfect horse picture
item.description: The old saying goes, "Never work with kids and animals" but for photographers it is part of the job description.

item.title: UK’s ‘unsung army’ of full-time unpaid carers needs more support, report says
item.description: A growing “unsung army” of 1 million people with full-time caring responsibilities needs better support, according to a report that found one in three unpaid carers from poorer backgrounds were unable to work because of their duties.

item.title: Valentino Guseli's 'massive personal win' during big air final
item.description: Valentino Guseli may have missed a medal in the snowboard big air final, finishing in a hugely credible 10th place in Saturday night's final at the Livigno Snow Park.

item.title: Tasmania explores homebirths, AMA says focus should be making hospitals comfortable
item.description: The Tasmanian government is developing a public homebirth model that would allow midwives working in the public system to support women to labour from their homes.

item.title: Olympic quick hits: Skier wears tank top, Carey lip-syncing drama emerges
item.description: Mariah Carey faces claims she was lip-syncing at the opening ceremony, while a Finnish skier makes a questionable fashion choice on the slopes.

item.title: Australia's men and women make perfect start to Perth Sevens
item.description: Australia's rugby sevens men are rallying around Will Cartwright after the 22-year-old dislocated his shoulder in the opening minutes of their hoodoo-busting 21-14 win over New Zealand in the world series event in Perth.

item.title: The Super Bowl half-time shows that became controversial flashpoints
item.description: For a show that lasts roughly 13 minutes, the Super Bowl half-time performance has fuelled decades of controversy.

item.title: On the streets of Melbourne: wild and wonderful people by Hussein Abdirahman Mohamud – in pictures
item.description: STREET by Hussein Abdirahman Mohamud is a zine published by the Centre for Contemporary Photography and Perimeter Editions, and is part of the CCP.

item.title: How the Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras after party fell apart
item.description: As the annual Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras protest parade reaches the end of Oxford Street each year and moves into the Entertainment Quarter, it turns into a party.

item.title: Arundell hat-trick fires England to emphatic Six Nations win against Wales
item.description: No surprises here, not even a hint of one.

item.title: Sussan Ley's ousting will be justified by this narrative
item.description: A permission structure has been crafted for Liberals to ditch the first woman to lead the federal party room before she has even had a year in the role.

item.title: Suryakumar’s brilliant blitz denies USA seismic shock in India’s T20 World Cup opener
item.description: There was, in the end, no shock – but there was not a lot of awe either.

item.title: Speedskater Francesca Lollobrigida wins host Italy’s first gold medal of the Milan Cortina Olympics
item.description: MILAN (AP) — Speedskater Francesca Lollobrigida won host Italy’s first gold medal of the Milan Cortina Games on Saturday, taking the women’s 3,000 meters in an Olympics-record time.

item.title: The 'reclusive spinster' artist who shunned conformity and embraced freedom
item.description: Gwen John lived her life refusing to bow to what was expected of a woman born in the Victorian era.

item.title: Avocados are a Super Bowl staple – but are they truly a miracle food?
item.description: Americans are expected to devour nearly 280m pounds of avocados during Super Bowl weekend.

item.title: Fernandes keeps Carrick’s perfect Manchester United record intact after Romero red card
item.description: Michael Carrick’s Manchester United revival has a fourth consecutive league win, while Thomas Frank’s Tottenham sink further, with still no victory in the competition in 2026.

item.description: It was all going a little too easy for Lindsey Vonn.

item.title: Bangers and smash: Von Allmen wins first gold of Winter Olympics to fulfil butcher’s dream
item.description: When the Swiss skier Franjo von Allmen first broke through in the junior ranks, his village butcher created a special sausage – the Silberblitz-Wurscht or Silver Lightning – in his honour.

item.title: Franjo von Allmen of Switzerland wins men’s downhill, first gold medal of Milan Cortina Games
item.description: BORMIO, Italy (AP) — Swiss racer Franjo von Allmen captured the Olympic downhill Saturday to win the first gold medal at the Milan Cortina Games.

item.description: Alex Ferlazzo will fly the Australian flag as the men's single luge competition gets underway at the Milano Cortina Olympics.

item.title: Never mind the lit-bros: Infinite Jest is a true classic at 30

item.title: Wealthy use loophole to conceal value of £300m in Scottish land sales

item.title: 'I want my ex-husband Steve Wright to come clean'
item.description: The ex-wife of serial killer Steve Wright has spoken of the abuse she suffered at his hands and how she hopes he will tell the truth about his victims.

item.title: Dow Jones hits 50,000 milestone amid tech gains and hopes of lower interest rates

item.title: Iran says ‘good start’ made in talks with US over nuclear programme
